node.title: Define thermal conductivity and specific heat in the HeatConductionMaterial. Thermal conductivity and specific heat are functions of temperature.
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question

Define thermal conductivity and specific heat in the HeatConductionMaterial. Thermal conductivity and specific heat are functions of temperature.
[thermal_conductivity_1]
type = HeatConductionMaterial
temp = T
min_T = 298
# thermal_conductivity = 5
# specific_heat = 100
thermal_conductivity_temperature_function = cla_cond
specific_heat_temperature_function = cla_spe
block = 1
[]
[cla_spe]
type = PiecewiseLinear
x = '300 400 640 1090 1093 1113 1133 1153 1173 1193 1213 1233 1248 2098 2099'
y = '281 302 331 375 502 590 615 719 816 770 619 469 356 356 356'
[]
[cla_cond]
type = ParsedFunction
Expression = 7.51 + t * 2.09 * 10 ^ (2) - 1.45 * 10 ^ (5) * t ^ 2 + 7.67 * 10 ^ (9) * t ^ 3
[]
[]
In the [cla_cond] equation, it seems that t here is no longer the time variable, does t variable represent the temperature variable? Is this way feasible?

Define thermal conductivity and specific heat in the HeatConductionMaterial. Thermal conductivity and specific heat are functions of temperature.
[thermal_conductivity_1]
type = HeatConductionMaterial
temp = T
min_T = 298
# thermal_conductivity = 5
# specific_heat = 100
thermal_conductivity_temperature_function = cla_cond
specific_heat_temperature_function = cla_spe
block = 1
[]
[cla_spe]
type = PiecewiseLinear
x = '300 400 640 1090 1093 1113 1133 1153 1173 1193 1213 1233 1248 2098 2099'
y = '281 302 331 375 502 590 615 719 816 770 619 469 356 356 356'
[]
[cla_cond]
type = ParsedFunction
Expression = 7.51 + t * 2.09 * 10 ^ (2) - 1.45 * 10 ^ (5) * t ^ 2 + 7.67 * 10 ^ (9) * t ^ 3
[]
[]

In the [cla_cond] equation, it seems that t here is no longer the time variable, does t variable represent the temperature variable? Is this way feasible?

t now representes the tiemperature variable when it is used in a HeatConductionMaterial.
To still have time in the equation, you need to do a trick, add this:
[Postprocessors]
  [time_pp]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    expression = 't'
    use_t = true
  []
[]

then in the ParsedFunction for cla_cond, whenever you need time instead of temperature, instead of using t, use time_pp
Remember that you have to declare it in the symbols_names (you can use anything you want there to represent the time_pp pp) and values (you have to refer to the time_pp there)
Thank you very much

@GiudGiud Dear expert
I want to develop a simple nuclear fuel performance analysis program similar to Bison, do you know about using moose to develop such a program?

Hello
It's certainly possible since that's how Bison is made. You can use the Bison documentation to help
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/bison/

@GiudGiud  ∆ρ , the total amount of densification that can occur as a percent of fuel theoretical density，I'm not sure what the value of this maximum density change is, and the Bison Theory manual doesn't give it, do you know？

Hello
You'll have to find this in the open litterature. Use something reasonable you may find for another fuel type until you find the real value
Guillaume
thanks

node.title: Split boundary processed by XYDelaunayGenerator
node.bodyText:
hello
The grid processed by XYDelaunayGenerator will merge the outer boundary of the geometry. How can I restore the previous boundary。I  need the previous rmax, dmin and dmax boundaries.
[annular]
type = AnnularMeshGenerator
nr = 15
rmin = 0
rmax = 0.005
nt = 24
dmin = 0
dmax = 90
equal_area = true
[]
[triangulates]
type = XYDelaunayGenerator
boundary = annular
[]
Thanks

Hello
If there is not a parameter in the triangulator to do this, then simply re add that boundary with ParsedGenerateSideset
Circular boundaries are each to get an analytical expression for

Hello
I think we are still avoiding mvapich on sawtooth with moose. There is a bug on sparse communications mvapich folks are not fixing.
Try with openmpi
@milljm
Eigen/Core is supposed to be in libmesh/contrib/eigen so it's odd it's showing up as missing
Guillaume

It looks like you have a built version of a moose module loaded:
LIBMESH_DIR=/apps/herd/moose/moose-2024-04-27/libmesh
PETSC_DIR=/apps/herd/moose/moose-2024-04-27/petsc

You shouldn't have these environment variables set when you're trying to build your own versions of PETSc, libMesh, WASP, and moose.
What you should be doing if you are developing in MOOSE, is to load the moose-dev module only:
module purge
module load use.moose moose-dev

Thank you for your help, I used that and started a new installation of MOOSE and now I am getting this error. Is there anyway I could reset my account and start from scratch? I must have missed something in the directions because this shouldn't be this hard. Don't use Sawtooth3. That is a visualization headnode. Use either sawtooth1 or sawtooth2.
At the time of when these instructions were created, only Sawtooth1 and 2 were available. I will create a PR to modify the instruction to make this more apparent.

Is there anyway I could reset my account and start from scratch?

This should not be necessary, as you have full control over your home directory (which is shared between all INL HPC clusters). Starting over is as simple as deleting the things you have created. In the case of MOOSE, you probably should start over before building on sawtooth1 or 2:
cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
git submodule foreach --recursive git clean -xfd
Should do the trick!
Awesome thank you so much, this may be a dumb question but how would I get to sawtooth 1 or 2?

Sorry for the delayed response,
You should be able to reach sawtooth1 or sawtooth2 via the HPC OnDemand portal, and then navigating the menu such as: Clusters, _Sawtooth1 Shell Access, or _Sawtooth2 Shell Access.

From the console if you are already logged in with ssh, you can switch to another sawtooth node with
ssh sawtooth1

node.title: updated MOOSE and it doesnt converge when PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative is active
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
I have just updated MOOSE to the latest version and for some reason when have PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative in my input file (to make simulation transient) it won't converge at all, the steady-state run works fine:
  [PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative]
    type = PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative
    ### see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative.html
    variable = porepressure_L1
    fluid_component = 0
    multiply_by_density = true
  []

Here is the input: https://github.com/Traiwit/public_moose_beh/blob/main/input_file_transient_doesnt_converge.i
Not sure if this is related to New initial residual evaluation behaviour
or the node number system has been updated (since we have nodal-constraints action)  [this shouldnt be the case since SS run works fine], etc

Traiwit

Hello
You can check whether the new initial residual behavior is causing the problem by reverting to the old one
It s a parameter in the Problem. Something like use_smo_residual

I tried to add use_pre_SMO_residual to [Executioner] > doesn't help
I also add TIMESTEP_BEGIN to all the execute_on flags > doesn't help
I now will try to output the results at every NONLINEAR step to see what's wrong with it, maybe the IC isnt projected properly (just a guess)
update: IC seems to be projected correctly. I dont know where to look anymore

@lindsayad @cpgr any relevant change you can think of with regards to porous flow or transients?
Otherwise you will have to git-bisect this. It s a good skill to have when working with codes being updated all the time
I don't think anything has changed with that kernel? It looks like the initial residual is the same in both cases, just that the solver isn't converging with the newer moose?

The initial residual evaluations are all different in the last few printed digits, between old moose, new moose pre-smo, and new moose post-smo, which concerns me a bit.
boomeramg does appear to be a mediocre preconditioner here. To test whether the "physics"/residuals have truly changed I would try to run with a stronger preconditioner, see if you can get the solve to converge, and then see whether the results are the same as before within tolerance. If you cannot get a converged result even with a stronger preconditioner, I would test whether your preconditioning matrix is a good representation of the operator using -snes_test_jacobian on a smaller problem.
A bisect can be a good debugging choice. I might give it a shot here

It's doubtful that there have been significant changes to the bt or boomeramg behavior otherwise I think we would have picked it up in our test harness, which runs tens of thousands of tests of bt and hundreds (to thousands?) of tests of boomeramg

Thanks @lindsayad
a quick note that: I have tried 3 of my most used line_searchs (bt, default, none), and none of them works.
I will try different preconditioners first thing on Monday, do you have any suggestion on the 'stronger preconditioner' for this kind of problem?

Strongest of them all is LU, the direct solve.
There are others, best place to find a list is the petsc documentation

LU with new MOOSE is the same, doesn't converge as fast as the old one, I also tested LU with old moose too, it works fine (though Linear is 3x slower than boomeramg).
does this mean we can no longer update MOOSE with our framework? :(

node.title: How to couple moose with an external Fortran program
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

node.title: Applying traction/force boundary conditions in Peridynamics module
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I was able to apply displacement boundary conditions in Peridynamics module. But I am unable to apply traction boundary conditions. As suggested in one of the previous discussion, I have tried using 'Constantrate' for force boundary condition (for simple tension test). But, as the mesh size changes, the displacement order changes significantly in such a way that I couldn't corelate the mesh size with constant force applied. I also tried applying pressure condition in NOSPD, but it shows some segmentation fault error. In Peridynamics module also, there is no example for traction bcs.
Please help me in this. I need to know how  'Constantrate' kernel can be used for force loading. Secondly, how else a traction boundary condition can be applied (other than using Pressure BC). It would be very helpful if an input file for simple tension test can be shared.
@hchen139 @bwspenc

I think you can applied traction boundary conditions in the PD module by either converting the traction to total force and distribute the force to nodes on the boundary and use the Constant Rate option, or construct fictitious finite elements for the boundary and use NeumannBC to apply as if you were doing FEA. For Constant Rate, you will need to update the value for different mesh density. For constructing fictitious finite element for PD, there are examples in the /tests/mesh directory.

From the problem (as a restart) or from the command line?
Guillaume

Can you try a recover from the command line?

Problem block,

force_restart is only for restart from multiapps. I recommend you remove this unless this is in a multiapp

node.title: [Q:] can the homogenization within new TM system be utilized to plasticity not only elasticity ?
node.bodyText:
Dear TM-developers,
Introduction
The homogenization of new system is working well in all of the elasticity problem no matter small and finite strain,
But if I changed the material to plasticity, the average cell value (homogenzied) is not correct and only present
the elastic response.
Interesting
the output of effective Plastic strain is correct.
Q
could you as experts re-implement the plastic problem under the homogenization of new system ?
By the way
dose this kind of method for presenting homogenization have bad-effect on the convergence of plastic problem especially in global (after assembly of finite element) ?
how to control this method related to the Macro-deformation gradient in finite strain ? especially in plasticity
Thanks so much
best regards,
tianwen

example.zip
here is test example, yeah, the homogeneous case is also sutiable to this homogenization system, I think.
Important Updating
I read a kind of report from ANL "Identify the influence of microstructure on mesoscale creep and fatigue damage" in 2020
almost 4 years ago.
one of sentence from it is  The current MOOSE constraint system is unsuited for implementing Multiple points (dummy nodes) types of conditions in 3D and so we examined other approaches. by Andrea Rovinelli
perhaps, I got misunderstanding for this homogenization system which should be fine at any material. I will check again.
A question to your issue. Did it work in the end as planned? I would also like to make the creep/viscoplastic homogenization using the new kernel system.

Dear Ross,
hi
answer:
the implementation of my own material based on the new system was not going well, unfortunately.
The unconverged problem occured at the FEproblem issues, maybe due to the "UserObjects" of homogenization.
By the way, you could try your model (eg. the viscoplasticity). This homogenization theory was not based on boundary-integral implemented by multiple-point-constraints method common in commercial software, like abaqus Equation. though they are similar from theoretical part, the implementation has some problem for me.
if you wanna focus on this point, see this report ANL "Identify the influence of microstructure on mesoscale creep and fatigue damage" in 2020.
Thanks
kind regards,
tianwen

Dear Tianwen,
thank you very much for your response. I will look into the report from ANL you mentioned.
Best regards,
Rostyslav.

I had the same problem with the standard creep model. If the homogeneous material properties are given into the homogenization framework, the system's output converges to the right value. However, if creep parameters vary across different blocks, the output diverges.

Hi, moose-developers,
sorry this borthering. my issues about this had already solved personally due to the problem of my code.
this discussion will be closed.
Thanks
tianwen

node.title: PressureBC on Annular Cylindrical Mesh Convergence Issue
node.bodyText:
I am trying to simulate a pipe, in which a constant force is applied on its inner surface. I am trying to use the LinearPiecewise function alongside the PressureBC to do the same. However the solution does not seem to converge after the first time step. Also ,is there a way to define the boundary conditions in a better way (like in cylindrical coordinates) and is this the best way to create a annular cylinder.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
        [annular]
                type = AnnularMeshGenerator
                nr = 10
                rmin = 7.5
                rmax = 10.0
                nt = 40
        []
        [make3D]
                type = MeshExtruderGenerator
                extrusion_vector = '0 0 40'
                num_layers = 10
                bottom_sideset = 'bottom'
                top_sideset = 'top'
                input = annular
        []
[]

[Variables]
  [temp]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 300.0
  []
[]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  [all]
    strain = FINITE
    incremental = true
    add_variables = true
    use_automatic_differentiation = true
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [top_pull]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 1'
    y = '1 1'
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [heat]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = temp
  []
  [heat_ie]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = temp
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [x_top_pull]
    type = ADPressure
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = rmin
    factor = -10.0e6
    function = top_pull
  []
  [y_top_pull]
    type = ADPressure
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = rmin
    factor = -10.0e6
    function = top_pull
  []
  [z_top_pull]
    type = ADPressure
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = rmin
    factor = -10.0e6
    function = top_pull
  []
  [temp_fix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    boundary = 'rmin rmax'
    value = 300.0
  []
  [top_fix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = top
    value = 0
  []
  [bottom_fix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 9e10
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  []
  [radial_return_stress]
    type = ADComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'power_law_creep'
  []
  [power_law_creep]
    type = ADPowerLawCreepStressUpdate
    coefficient = 1.0e-15
    n_exponent = 4
    activation_energy = 3.0e5
    temperature = temp
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./Volume]
    type = VolumePostprocessor
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./Volumetric_Strain]
    type = ChangeOverTimePostprocessor
    postprocessor = Volume
    change_with_respect_to_initial = true
    compute_relative_change = true
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./Strain_Rate]
    type = ChangeOverTimePostprocessor
    postprocessor = Volumetric_Strain
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  scheme = BDF2
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  l_tol = 1.0e-2
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-4
  start_time = 0.0
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  num_steps = 1e9
  steady_state_detection = true
  steady_state_tolerance = 1.0e-16
  [./TimeStepper]
   type = IterationAdaptiveDT
   cutback_factor = 0.75
   dt = 1.0
   growth_factor = 1.2
   optimal_iterations = 7
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  [out]
    type = Checkpoint
    num_files = 1
  []
[]

Hello
We do not support R-theta-z coodinates but you could define the problem in RZ coordinates.
I think it would be a good check on your results as well.
I dont see the interaction between temperature and displacements here? You should try to converge each problem independently first to identify issues
Guillaume

Hey
Thanks for the reply.
As far as i know, the RZ coordinates rotates a 1d or 2d mesh, to create the cylindrical structure.  Would i be able to define the thickness radius and length of the pipe using this system?
A 2D mesh in RZ can define both the radius (R direction, or x) and a length of a pipe (Z direction, or y)
I do also want the pipe to have some thickness that is it should have some inner radius r, some outer radius R and some length l.
You can model thickness too in RZ, it can be represented on the same axis as the radius
how exactly would i do that? Could you show me an example or some test case?

something like this?
thickness_inner = 1
thickness_mid = 2
thickness_outer = 3
[Mesh]

[]

multiple regions (blocks) in x (=R) for each thickness

So when i use  the coord_type = 'RZ' what exactly changes in this mesh. Like is x analogous to r and y to z? And how do the boundaries change? Does top become rmin and bottom become rmax, and something for left and right as well?
